body:
> minimal.lua

Is this _really_ minimal? I.e., a simple `vim.treesitter.start()` in a `FileType markdown` autocommand won't trigger it? Is `render-markdown` doing anything treesitter related? If so, can you try to isolate it? That would help a lot.

(At least you should be able to remove nvim-treesitter from the config.)
(Note that there haven't been noteworthy changes to the async parsing since 0.11 was released, so I'd be surprised if you can't reproduce it on a 0.11 appimage.)

Second point first: I've been on HEAD forever. I only installed `render-markdown` a few days ago, unrelated to the release of 0.11. Later today, I will try to bisect to a commit.

First point: fair question, but I think it is minimal. With no plugins:

1. the file opens with no problem,
2. a simple `vim.treesitter.start()` throws no error, and 
3. `:Inspect` works as expected.

So, `render-markdown` is how I can produce this error, _possibly_ because it uses `parse` a lot. And it has `nvim-treesitter` as a dependency. I don't know if the bug could be reproduced simply by calling `parse` in a tight loop. Maybe @MeanderingProgrammer might have an idea.

> And it has nvim-treesitter as a dependency.

It shouldn't be, though. That's the first thing to fix. And please test the release 0.11 appimage first; bisecting to an exact commit in the 0.11 dev cycle is not as useful. (Things have been reworked too much for 0.11 for this to be an easily fixed small regression in a single commit.)

> And it has nvim-treesitter as a dependency.

`nvim-treesitter` is not needed as a dependency strictly speaking. I remember adding this at some point when parsers would sometimes not be available on the runtime path unless `nvim-treesitter` was sourced first. I think this stems from `0.9.0` behavior. Shouldn't be an issue with any newer versions.

The other purpose of the dependency is just to make sure highlights are enabled which is done through the highlights module. This part can be replaced with a `FileType` autocommand and a call to `vim.treesitter.start` like you said.

The plugin doesn't actually call into `nvim-treesitter` for any functionality.

I imagine my plugin is triggering this error due to its repeated calls to parse, there should be a way to trigger it without the plugin directly. Maybe using the autocommand + a rough approximation of how it calls parse within the callback.

With that additional info, a new `minimal.lua` without `nvim-treesitter`:
```lua
for name, url in pairs {
  "https://github.com/MeanderingProgrammer/render-markdown.nvim",
} do
  local install_path = vim.fn.fnamemodify("nvim_issue/" .. name, ":p")
  if vim.fn.isdirectory(install_path) == 0 then
    vim.fn.system { "git", "clone", "--depth=1", url, install_path }
  end
  vim.opt.runtimepath:append(install_path)
end

require("render-markdown").setup {}

vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('FileType', {
  pattern = 'markdown',
  callback = function (event)
    vim.treesitter.start(event.buf, 'markdown')
  end
})
```

More importantly, using the 11.0 release tarball (on a mac at the moment), I don't reproduce the error.
```
❯ nvim -v
NVIM v0.12.0-dev-71+g0b61bc8982
Build type: RelWithDebInfo
LuaJIT 2.1.1741730670
Run "nvim -V1 -v" for more info

❯ nvim --clean -u minimal.lua parser.md
# errors

❯ ./nvim-macos-arm64/bin/nvim -v
NVIM v0.11.0
Build type: Release
LuaJIT 2.1.1741730670
Run "nvim -V1 -v" for more info

❯ ./nvim-macos-arm64/bin/nvim --clean -u minimal.lua parser.md
# no errors

I'm able to reproduce this with a combination of 2 things:

1. Running parse inside a `vim.schedule`
2. A fairly large & complex file, it seems like large on its own is not enough, I imagine it's something to do with how long it takes for neovim to finish parsing, but just a guess

I'm able to get this error fairly consistently with this `minimal.lua`:

```lua
vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('FileType', {
    pattern = 'markdown',
    callback = function(event)
        local buf = event.buf
        vim.treesitter.start(buf, 'markdown')
        vim.schedule(function()
            assert(vim.treesitter.get_parser(buf)):parse({ 0, 80 })
        end)
    end,
})
```

And using the README from my repo: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/MeanderingProgrammer/render-markdown.nvim/refs/heads/main/README.md

I'd paste it here but it's long, seems like 800 lines is the tipping point, but it's pretty inconsistent and sometimes smaller files will run into the error.

> More importantly, using the 11.0 release tarball (on a mac at the moment), I don't reproduce the error.

OK, then a bisect from the 0.11 release to HEAD should be quick and helpful.

Also seen in CI: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/actions/runs/14245003687/job/39923664812?pr=33283

```
ERROR    test/functional/treesitter/parser_spec.lua @ 217: treesitter parser API resets when buffer was editing during an async parse
test/functional/testnvim.lua:136: Error executing lua: ...eovim/neovim/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/languagetree.lua:406: attempt to yield across C-call boundary
stack traceback:
	[C]: in function 'yield'
	...eovim/neovim/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/languagetree.lua:406: in function '_parse_regions'
	...eovim/neovim/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/languagetree.lua:618: in function '_parse'
	...eovim/neovim/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/languagetree.lua:585: in function 'parse'
	[string "<nvim>"]:1: in main chunk

stack traceback:
	test/functional/testnvim.lua:136: in function 'exec_lua'
	test/functional/treesitter/parser_spec.lua:243: in function <test/functional/treesitter/parser_spec.lua:217>
```
I've bisected and can confirm the errors start with f4fc769
